The FRB, western Canada’s largest Pacific River watershed, spans one-quarter of BC from its headwaters in the Rocky Mountains to its outlet to the Pacific Ocean at Vancouver
1 (Fig. 1). Collecting water from its vast network of tributaries, it accumulates Canada’s third-highest mean annual flow (3,972 m 3 s −1), which is largely snowmelt-driven
1 . The Fraser River is a critically important waterway for BC’s communities, ecosystems, and economy. It remains one of the most important wild salmonid-producing rivers globally and supports runs of five species of Pacific salmon: Chinook, chum, coho, pink and sockeye
2, 3 . Among these, sockeye is the most important both culturally and economically
4, 5 . Salmon spawn as far inland as 1500 km from the mouth of the Fraser and their successful return to natal spawning areas depends on seasonal variability of flows and water temperature
6, 7 . As a result, natural or human-induced changes in the flow and/or thermal characteristics of the FRB can induce considerable impacts on these species.
